title: Chicago Bears' field goal heartbreak deepens with Eddy Pineiro's game-costing missed kick
text:
CLOSE Check out some early NFL headlines. USA TODAY

The Chicago Bears, with a potentially game-winning kick on the horizon Sunday against the Los Angeles Chargers, had the chance to gain extra yards to make it a little easier for Eddy Pineiro.

Instead, coach Matt Nagy opted for Chicago quarterback Mitchell Trubisky to take a knee after he gained 11 yards on a scramble that got Chicago to the Chargers' 21-yard line. Even though there were 53 seconds left on the clock, Nagy called a quarterback kneel and then used his final timeout with four seconds left in the game to set up a 41-yard kick for Pineiro.

Pineiro’s kick appeared to start on target but ten hooked wide left. The Bears lost, 17-16, dropping Chicago to 3-4.

After the loss, Nagy stood by his decision.

"I’ll just be brutally clear: zero thought of throwing the football, zero through of running the football," Nagy said. "You understand me? That’s exactly what it was. It’s as simple as that.”

It was Pineiro’s second missed field goal of the day. He made three attempts, from 22, 25 and 19 yards away.

This was just the latest mishap in Chicago’s recent history of kicking. The team is still dealing with the effects of Jannuary's missed "double-doink" field goal attempt by Cody Parkey that cost Chicago its chance to advance through the wild-card round of the playoffs against the Philadelphia Eagles.

Parkey converted 23 of 30 (76.7%) attempts last season and made three of four tries in that 16-15 wild card round loss. The missed game-winner in last year’s playoffs was partially blocked and then caromed off of the left upright before hitting the crossbar and falling to the turf.

The Bears later cut Parkey and held an open competition in training camp in which Pineiro was declared the winner.

Pineiro, after his two misses Sunday, is now 12 of 15 on the season in field goal tries.

“I really like where we’re at,” Nagy said concerning Pineiro’s future status with the team. “I have ultimate faith in him. I do. It just happens to be in our situation it gets completely magnified because of where we’ve been before, but I have ultimate trust in him. He’s going to be the first to tell you that he wants to come back out here and he wants another opportunity at that shot, at that kick. All we can do is next time we get that opportunity, he puts it right down the middle.”

description: The Bears were haunted all offseason by a missed field goal that ended their season. On Sunday, another miss cost them a win vs. the Chargers.
